com.github.dm.jrt.core.invocation

Class InvocationFactory<IN,OUT>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.dm.jrt.core.util.DeepEqualObject
      • com.github.dm.jrt.core.invocation.InvocationFactory<IN,OUT>
  • Type Parameters:
    IN - the input data type.
    OUT - the output data type.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CommandInvocation, DecoratingInvocationFactory, MappingInvocation

    public abstract class InvocationFactory<IN,OUT>
extends DeepEqualObject
    Abstract class defining an invocation factory.
    The inheriting class must specify the constructor arguments to be used in the equals() and hashCode() implementations. Like for example: 
         

         public class MyFactory extends InvocationFactory<String, Integer> {

             public MyFactory(final String regex) {
                 super(Reflection.asArgs(regex));
                 mRegex = regex;
             }

             ...
         }
    Or null, in case the constructor takes no arguments: 
         

         public class MyFactory extends InvocationFactory<String, Integer> {

             public MyFactory() {
                 super(null);
             }

             ...
         }

    Created by davide-maestroni on 02/12/2015.

      • factoryOf

        @NotNull
public static <IN,OUT> InvocationFactory<IN,OUT> factoryOf(@NotNull
                                                                    Class<? extends Invocation<IN,OUT>> invocationClass,
                                                                    @Nullable
                                                                    Object... args)
        Builds and returns a new invocation factory creating instances of the specified class by passing the specified arguments to the class constructor.

        Note that inner and anonymous classes can be passed as well. Remember however that Java creates synthetic constructors for such classes, so be sure to specify the correct arguments to guarantee proper instantiation. In fact, inner classes always have the outer instance as first constructor parameter, and anonymous classes have both the outer instance and all the variables captured in the closure.

        Type Parameters:
        IN - the input data type.
        OUT - the output data type.
        Parameters:
        invocationClass - the invocation class.
        args - the invocation constructor arguments.
        Returns:
        the invocation factory.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no constructor taking the specified objects as parameters was found.

      • factoryOf

        @NotNull
public static <IN,OUT> InvocationFactory<IN,OUT> factoryOf(@NotNull
                                                                    ClassToken<? extends Invocation<IN,OUT>> invocationToken,
                                                                    @Nullable
                                                                    Object... args)
        Builds and returns a new invocation factory creating instances of the specified class token by passing the specified arguments to the class constructor.

        Note that class tokens of inner and anonymous classes can be passed as well. Remember however that Java creates synthetic constructors for such classes, so be sure to specify the correct arguments to guarantee proper instantiation. In fact, inner classes always have the outer instance as first constructor parameter, and anonymous classes have both the outer instance and all the variables captured in the closure.

        Type Parameters:
        IN - the input data type.
        OUT - the output data type.
        Parameters:
        invocationToken - the invocation class token.
        args - the invocation constructor arguments.
        Returns:
        the invocation factory.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no constructor taking the specified objects as parameters was found.

Remember however that Java creates synthetic constructors for such classes, so be sure to specify the correct arguments to guarantee proper instantiation. In fact, inner classes always have the outer instance as first constructor parameter, and anonymous classes have both the outer instance and all the variables captured in the closure.

        Type Parameters:

      • newInvocation

        @NotNull
public abstract Invocation<IN,OUT> newInvocation()
                                                   throws Exception
        Creates and return a new invocation instance.
        A proper implementation will return a new invocation instance each time it is called, unless the returned object is immutable and does not cause any side effect.
        Any behavior other than that may lead to unexpected results.
        Returns:
        the invocation instance.
        Throws:
        Exception - if an unexpected error occurs.
